text: Hey, what's up creators? My name is Luke
and welcome back to the first hour of
Unreal Engine course. In this video,
we're going to be showing you how we can
take our coin counter that we created as
part of our widget blueprint in the last
video and showing you how we can
actually bind it to the programming that
we've got. So, when we collect a coin,
the number is going to go up. It's going
to be a very quick video. That being
said, let's jump straight into Unreal
Engine and make it happen. So, inside of
Unreal Engine, what I've done is I've
just made sure that my coins, I've just
got them scattered around the level. As
before, I just had them sort of lined up
one by one, all five of them in the
center. So, now if I press play, you can
see I can collect each of them
individually. I've got one in the center
and then one in each of the corners. But
most importantly, that coin counter in
the top right hand corner does not match
up with the print strings that we've
got. So, let's show you now how we can
actually join the two of these up. We're
going to go to our content drawer and
we're going to go to our first hour of
Unreal Engine folder and we're going to
open up our widget blueprint_HUD.
Inside of here, we're going to find our
coin counter and we're just going to
leftclick on it. And you're going to see
inside of here, we have got our text and
it's currently set to 0 0. That means
our text is going to be set to 0 0 the
whole time. And that's where this button
comes in. There's a little binding
button that you can click. It looks like
a link button. We can click on that and
we can create a binding. So the very
first thing that we're going to do once
we've created that binding is we're
going to find it under our functions and
we're just going to rename this and
we're just going to rename it to um
binding
um coin counter.
And then once we've done that, we can
now actually start working on our
blueprint code in here to actually
collect the information and display it.
So what I want you to do is just break
this link here again just by hovering
over the line, holding down alt, and
then left clicking on it. Then what
we're going to do is cast to our
character. So that way we can actually
ask it what the value of our coins
collected is. So to do that, we're going
to drag out from execute. We are going
to type in cast 2 and then platformer
character and we're going to find it.
And if you remember, it's called
bp_platforming
character. So if you can't find it, cast
to bp_platforming
character. And make sure you just choose
the top one there. And then with this,
the type of object for this is a
character, the player's character
specifically. So drag out from object
and we're just going to search for get
player character.
Then once we've done that, we've now got
access to this pin which is going to
give us direct access to that variable.
So, as our BP platforming character,
what we can do now is simply get coins.
And the one that we're after
specifically is get collected coins. So,
we're now asking it how many coins has
it got essentially. And we're going to
drag and put this into the return node,
which is just going to convert that
number to some text and put it into that
text field. And now
we can do the return as soon as we
finish this cast.
Hit compile.
And that's it. We can now just press
play. It says zero in the top right hand
corner. I can collect a coin. You can
see it's gone up to one. I'm going to go
over. I'm going to collect another coin.
Another one all the way until I get to
number five. So, I can see I've only got
one more to collect. I'm just going to
sprint over. And you can see there once
it gets to five, my game is going to
pause. So with all of that done, we now
know how we can actually display
information such as how many coins are
being collected on the user interface.
It does not have to stop here. It
doesn't just have to be that. There's so
so many more things that we can do with
all of this. That being said, that's
everything that I wanted to show you as
part of this video. If you feel like
I've gone a little bit too fast or it
doesn't quite work for you, feel free to
just go back to the video, find the
content of my binding and just copy
exactly what I've got here and it's
going to work for you. Move on to the
next video to continue your Unreal
Engine learning journey. Specifically,
we're going to be showing you how to set
up all of the visuals of our headsup
display. As always, I hope you have
enjoyed it. Stay awesome. Keep creating.
